synonyms: disorders of consciousness, vegetative state  speech therapy
coma, disorders of consciousness: speech therapy
speech therapy: disorders of consciousness, coma
and minimally conscious state: speech therapy
anatomical location body part affected: The brain; the entire individual is ultimately affected by disorders of consciousness/coma
description: Disorders of consciousness include coma, unresponsive wakefulness syndrome (UWS), and minimally conscious state (MCS)(1)

Coma –A state of pathological unconsciousness; a major complication of disorders and trauma that affect the CNS(1,32) –Consciousness is depressed and the eyes remain closed at all times; individual is unresponsive. The patient might exhibit reflexive movements with repeated vigorous sensory stimuli(1,2,32) –There is a complete loss of spontaneous or stimulus-induced arousal.(32) While in a coma, the patient is unarousable; however, he or she might exhibit some reflexive movements(1)

UWS –Typically follows coma(2) –The patient shows improvement from initial comatose state; he or she typically appears awake and remains motionless without awareness of self or surroundings(1,32) –The term UWS was coined in 2010 and is often used to describe a disordered state of consciousness also called vegetative state (VS).(35,36)The term vegetative state is controversial. Some feel that the term is pejorative, as it bears similarity to the word “vegetable”; others feel that the term conflates consciousness and behavioral responsiveness.(32)Because the term vegetative state is sometimes viewed as pejorative, and clinicians might feel uncomfortable referring to a patient in this way, the term UWS was introduced into the literature, and the state is sometimes referred to as VS/UWS(36)

MCS –A significantly altered state of consciousness distinct from coma and UWS owing to the presence of episodes of consciousness in which eye contact or goal-directed behavior occurs(2) –Individuals in an MCS demonstrate inconsistent periods of consciousness with some degree of functional recovery and responsive behavior(1) –Behavioral responses of individuals in an MCS indicate some level of self-awareness(3)  –Emergence from MCS is marked by recovery of interactive communication or functional object use(32) –For detailed information on patients in an MCS, see Clinical Review…Disorders of Consciousness, Minimally Conscious State: Speech Therapy : CINAHL Topic ID Number: T902216
This Clinical Review focuses on patients in a coma or VS/UWS

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: A patient in a coma will be unresponsive, with his or her eyes closed.(1) UWS typically follows a coma and the patient shows improvement from initial comatose state, appearing awake but remaining motionless and unaware of his or her surroundings. Patients in these disordered states of consciousness might present with abnormal breathing patterns and abnormal posturing and can develop joint contractures and decubitus ulcers over time as a result of being bedbound(1)

Decorticate posturing (the individual is stiff with arms bent in toward the body, clenched fists sometimes held on the chest, and legs straight out) can occur when there are lesions of the internal capsule and rostral cerebral peduncle(1)

Decerebrate posturing (arms and legs are held straight out, toes are pointed downward, and the head and neck are arched backwards) occurs when there is extensive brainstem damage that extends to the pons at the level of the trigeminal nerve(1)

Swallowing –The ability to swallow can return before a patient emerges from coma; however, in some cases a patient can regain full consciousness but have severe dysphagia(4) –If a patient cannot swallow his or her own saliva or does not have a strong cough, frequent suctioning for drooling might be necessary(4)

Locked-in  syndrome (de-efferented  state) –Caused by acute destructive lesions of the brainstem that damage the ventral pons while sparing the tegmentum(1) –Locked-in  syndrome presents similarly to a disorder of consciousness and must be differentiated from UWS. Patients are conscious and aware of their surroundings but unable to speak or move(1) –Typically, the prognosis for locked-in  syndrome is poor; however, recovery has been reported, including resumption of independence in ADLs(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: SLPs must be cautious in providing oral trials or starting therapeutic oral feedings with patients in states of disordered consciousness; patients should have achieved a level of consciousness of at least UWS (i.e., have emerged from a coma) and the physician should provide specific guidelines for appropriate oral trials (e.g., moistened swab, ice chips, water)(19,34)

In an evaluation of a patient in a state of disordered consciousness, the examiner is attempting to elicit behavioral responses through various types of stimulation, and therefore there is a risk that the patient could become agitated and/or combative

causes: coma and uws can result from a: Metabolic disturbances (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis, hepatic encephalopathy)(1,49)

Traumatic brain injury (TBI)(1,2,4,5)–Although TBI is a common cause of disorders of consciousness, researchers who conducted an Italian population studywith 600 patients with UWS or in an MCS found that the majority of cases were related to a nontraumatic etiology (e.g.,cardiac arrest with hypoxia)(42)–For detailed information on TBI, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
Anoxia(4,5,6,49)–Anoxia can result from cardiac arrest, drug or alcohol overdose, or other events(1,6,42)

Brain tumor(1,4)–For detailed information on brain tumor, see Clinical Review…Brain Tumors in Childhood: Speech Therapy ; CINAHLTopic ID Number: T708892 and Clinical Review…Brain Tumors; Adult – Speech Therapy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708860
Stroke(4,5,6,49)–For detailed information on speech therapy for stroke, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
Asphyxiation (as a result of hanging, drowning, choking, poisoning, or carbon monoxide or other gas intoxication)(7,49)

overall contraindications precautions: The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) must be aware of cultural considerations when assessing swallowing function as well as when developing treatment goals. Needs of the patient should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting  In many cultures, feeding a patient is associated with caring for and healing a sick family member; hence, the inability to feed an individual in a coma or UWS might be very distressing to the family(8)

A speech therapy assessment should include the patient and family/friends as appropriate; including the patient’s familial and social network in the rehabilitation process might assist in the patient’s psychosocial recovery(9)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Review medical chart and physician reports to ascertain information about the patient’s underlying condition -What caused the patient to be in a state of disordered consciousness? What circumstances surrounded the onset of the coma or UWS?(1) -Abrupt onset of coma is consistent with subarachnoid hemorrhage, brainstem stroke, and intracerebral hemorrhage; slow onset and gradual progression to unconsciousness suggests an underlying structural defect or mass lesion(1) -If an intoxicated state or agitated delirium precedes the comatose state, the cause is likely metabolic(1) -How long has the patient been in a coma or UWS?(1) -Review the patient’s medical chart to determine if the physician has made a statement regarding long-term  prognosis for consciousness(1)

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical or surgical management of the disorder of consciousness and underlying Management of swelling in the face and head; monitoring of intracranial pressure (ICP)(1) Craniotomy (evacuation of hematoma, placement of a ventriculoperitoneal [VP] shunt)(10,50) Airway management/intubation/mechanical ventilation(1) Induced therapeutic hypothermia is often used with patients who arrive at the hospital in a comatose state to prevent further neurological damage(7)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; how are they being taken? IV or feeding tube? Patients in a coma are typically given an IV that includes dextrose, naloxone, and thiamine (a “coma cocktail”)(1,11)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Diagnostic imaging (e.g., MRI, CT scan, chest X-ray)(1)
Functional MRI (fMRI) to determine presence and patterns of cerebral activation(12)

In a study conducted in Spain involving individuals with UWS or in an MCS after TBI, researchers found that cerebral activation occurred in response tohearing narratives read forward and backward despite no clinical response at bedside; in one individual in UWS and one individual in an MCS, the cerebral activation patterns were almost identical to those of healthy volunteers(12)

In a study conducted in Japan, researchers compared fMRIs in response to music stimulation of 21 healthy adults to those of 2 adults in an MCS and 5 with UWS. In this study, bilateral superior temporal gyri activation was present in the fMRIs of both the healthy adults and patients in MCSs; however, there was no response observed from the patients with UWS. Researchers proposed that cortical response to music stimulation might be a way to differentiate MCS and UWS(37)

In an fMRI study conducted in Germany with 6 patients with UWS, 6 patients in an MCS, and 17 healthy controls, researchers found that the weighted global connectivity (the extent to which voxels [“lit up” areas on the fMRI indicating cortical activation] are connected to other voxels, which was seen as an indication of functional neural recovery) was significantly greater in the MCS group compared to the UWS group.(38) The amount of weighted global connectivity in those patients in an MCS was similar to, but not as extensive as, that seen in the healthy controls(38)
Blood work (CBC, platelets, PT[INR], PTT, BUN, creatinine, serum glucose, electrolyte analysis, arterial blood gases [ABGs], toxicological studies as indicated)(1)
Event-related  potentials (ERPs) are measured with an EEG and sometimes used to develop prognosis(13)
A lack of somatosensoryevoked potentials (SEPs) is associated with an unfavorable prognosis for return of consciousness(13)
Functional neuroimaging to assess cerebral metabolism(13,14,15)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document the patient’s response to stimuli such as light, sound, touch, and pain(1)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms and preserved reflexes
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use scales that do not require verbal responses to assess pain response; use Oucher, FLACC scale, Adult Nonverbal Pain Scale (NVPS), Behavioral Pain Scale, or Critical Care Pain Observation Tool to document pain response -Note the behavioral response to painful stimuli(1) -Purposeful limb withdrawal from painful stimuli suggests that the patient’s sensory pathways from and motor pathways to the limb are intact(1) -An absence of a behavioral response to pain unilaterally suggests presence of a corticospinal lesion(1) -An absence of a response to pain bilaterally suggests damage to/involvement of the brainstem, bilateral pyramidal tract lesions, or psychogenic unresponsiveness(1)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing -Risk of DVT is significantly increased in patients with hemiplegia; assess for signs of DVT (e.g., redness, warmth, pain, tenderness, swelling) and refer to physician urgently if these symptoms are present
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient require mechanical ventilation? -Document abnormal breathing patterns -Cheyne-Stokes  respiration (episodes of deep breathing alternating with periods of apnea) can occur in cases of bihemispheric or diencephalic disease or comas caused by metabolic disorders(1) -Central neurogenic hyperventilation (marked by a rapid regular breathing pattern) can occur with lesions of the brainstem tegmentum(1) -Apneustic breathing (prolonged inspiratory phase followed by pauses with expiration; rate is usually around 1.5 breaths per minute) indicates lesions of the brainstem at the level of the pons(1) -Atactic breathing (very irregular breathing pattern with both shallow and deep breaths occurring randomly) indicates damage at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum and medulla(1)Document any history of hearing impairment or use of hearing aids Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Is there a prior history of coma or another disorder of consciousness? Is there a history of cardiovascular disease (e.g., stroke, hypertension, arterial stenosis)? Is there a history of cognitive, speech, language, or swallowing/feeding difficulties?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient’s family about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What activities/hobbies did the patient enjoy prior to the coma? -A caregiver interview might be helpful to gain insight into the patient’s hobbies, family/community roles, interests, prior work status, and home responsibilities
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What current assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be used based on patient’s current level of functioning? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -Who is the patient’s primary caregiver? -If the patient has no caregiver or the patient’s caregiver is not receiving guidance or assistance with the patient’s care, refer to social worker or case management -Family members of patients with disordered consciousness experience psychosocial distress, including feelings ofdisbelief, anger, sadness, apprehension, and depression(52) -There are typically high levels of burden associated with being a caregiver for a person in a state of disordered consciousness. In a study conducted in Italy with 487 participants who were caregivers to persons with UWS or in an MCS, researchers found that all caregivers reported high distress and burden.(39) In this study, the number of hours of daily caregiving required by the patient was significantly associated with the perceived level of caregiver burden.(39) Using the data from the same sample of 487 caregiving participants, researchers found in a subsequent study that caregivers who perceived a high level of burden also exhibited more signs of anxiety and depression.(40) In another study conducted in Italy with 418 informal caregivers of both children and adults with UWS or in an MCS, researchers found that female caregivers had poorer states of mental health than male caregivers; depressive symptoms in female caregivers affected both their physical and mental health(41) -With whom does the patient live (e.g., spouse/partner, parents, children, siblings, grandparents, caregivers)? -Identify if there are barriers to future age-appropriate  independence in the home; are any modifications necessary? -Inquire about the levels of the home, including stairs and number of floors

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: For patients who are in a coma, assistive and adaptive devices for communication are unlikely to be beneficial due to the lack of purposeful, intentional movements. However, for a patient who is emerging from a coma or UWS and regaining the ability to control even small movements such as eye blinks or hand closure, assistive technology can be introduced in order for the patient to communicate (e.g., make a request) or act on his or her environment (e.g., change the radio station)(9,10,16,17)  –For detailed information regarding the assessment for and use of augmentative or alternative communication (AAC) in speech therapy, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicComplete a full oral mechanism examination; assess passive ROM, strength, endurance, and movement rate for the lips, tongue, and soft palate, when possible –A complete assessment of oral mechanism is difficult in individuals in a state of disordered consciousness –Document reflexive responses to labial and lingual stimulation with ice, spoon, different tastes and textures
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Adults generally respond to a wider range of stimuli than children; for pediatric patients, familiar voices (such as those of the child’s parents or siblings) and familiar toys and objects should be used whenever possible(8)  –The American Congress of Rehabilitation Medicine, Brain Injury Interdisciplinary Special Interest Group, Disorders of Consciousness Task Force made evidence-based recommendations for clinical practice and research for disorders of -Coma Recovery Scale–Revised  (CRS-R)  (recommended, with minor reservations)(3) -A standardized behavioral assessment that measures neurobehavioral function in order to assist with differential diagnosis and document recovery from coma(22) -Comprises 23 items that are divided among 6 subscales; assesses auditory, visual, motor, oromotor, communication, and arousal functions(22) -Authors of a retrospective study conducted in Italy that included 19 individuals with UWS or in an MCS reported that misclassification between UWS and MCS was common if the diagnosis was based on a single administration of the CRS-R.  For the individuals in this study, scores were significantly higher and the individuals were significantly more likely to be classified as being in an MCS if the CRS-R  was administered in the morning versus the afternoon. Authors recommended multiple administrations of the CRS-R over many different times of day(47) T709271 -Coma/Near-Coma  Scale (CNC) (recommended, with major reservations)(3) -Disorders of Consciousness Scale (DOCS)(recommended, with moderate reservations)(3) -A standardized assessment with 23 test items; each item is rated on a 3-point  rating scale(8,13) -0 = No response; response does not differ from baseline behavior; 1 = General response; 2 = Localized response; response is contextually related to the test stimuli -SLPs can perform the DOCS to measure the level of fluctuating cognition for patients in states of disordered consciousness. One of the subtests is “Taste & Swallowing,”in which the assessor determines patient response to pre-swallowing stimulation as well as the ability to swallow within 15–20  seconds of stimulation(34) -The DOCS manual and testing forms are available free in the public domain(34) -The DOCS “Taste and Swallowing”subtest items do not involve providing any actual boluses to the patient; responses provide the assessor with baseline information regarding pre-swallowing  and swallowing abilities, level of cognitive functioning, and level of consciousness(34) -SLPs must be cautious in starting therapeutic oral feedings with patients in states of disordered consciousness. The baseline DOCS information can assist the SLP in determining if the patient is a candidate for an advanced swallowing
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examinationA motor speech evaluation should be performed (as possible) to detect the presence of apraxia or dysarthria(18) -Apraxia and dysarthria have been documented in individuals with severe brain injury emerging from UWS or MCS(18) -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of apraxia, see Clinical Review…Apraxia of Speech (Acquired) ;T708586 -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria (spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hypokinetic, and hyperkinetic), see the series of Clinical Reviews on these topicsComplete formal (if possible) or informal measures of language comprehension and expression to determine the presence of aphasia -Document behavioral responses to speech and other auditory stimuli; document if the patient responds more to familiar voices such as those of family members -For detailed information on aphasia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Document level of arousal; is the patient in a coma or UWS? Document the results of any diagnostic tests that have been completed to determine level of consciousness and/or prognosis for return of consciousness
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Assess swallowing function at bedside as able; progress slowly first, determining the patient’s ability to manage his or her own saliva/secretions followed by ice chips, small amounts of water, and then larger amounts of food and/or liquid per physician order.(8) Swallowing examinations should be performed only for patients who are functioning at a Rancho Los Amigos (RLA) level of cognitive functioning of II or greater(19) –Document need for and frequency of suctioning (orally or through a tracheostomy tube) as an informal measure of a patient’s ability to control his or her secretions; the more often the patient requires suctioning, the worse his or her ability to control/involuntarily swallow secretions(8) –For patients with UWS or in an MCS, it might be necessary to perform an instrumental evaluation of swallowing (such as a videofluoroscopic swallow study [VFSS] or fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing [FEES]) to rule out aspiration(19) -In a study conducted in the United States, researchers examined the feasibility of instrumental swallowing assessments in patients with prolonged disordered consciousness(19) -The 35 patients included in the study had experienced severe brain injuries and were all at an RLA level of cognitive functioning of II, II/III, or III and a cognitive score of 5 on the FIM (patients with UWS or in an MCS)(19,20) -The swallowing function of each patient in the study was examined with either VFSS or FEES(19) -At the time of the initial VFSS or FEES, all of the patients were NPO and 30 (86%) had a tracheostomy tube(19) -The participants were divided into two groups; Group 1 participants had a baseline VFSS or FEES earlier in their coma recovery relative to Group 2; however, Group 1 participants were able to safely tolerate both the swallowing examination and therapeutic feedings with an SLP during their stay in inpatient rehabilitation(19) -Additionally, the results of the study indicated that improvements in swallowing could be made in patients who did not demonstrate improved cognitive functioning as measured by the FIM(19) -Researchers suggested that swallowing evaluation and treatment be a part of rehabilitation programs for patients with disordered consciousness(19) –For detailed information on evaluations of swallowing disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on in-depth bedside swallowing evaluations and instrumental evaluations of swallowing (e.g., VFSS, FEES)
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. For detailed information on assessment of a tracheostomy tube and use of a speaking valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy & Ventilator Swallowing and Speaking Valve ; CINAHL Topic IDT708919

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Coma stimulation programs should provide stimulation that does not interfere with the patient’s medical care; for example, sensory stimulation should not result in a dangerous increase in ICP or blood pressure(25)

SLPs must be cautious in starting therapeutic oral feedings with patients in states of disordered consciousness; patients should have achieved a level of consciousness of at least UWS (i.e., have emerged from a coma)and the physician should provide specific guidelines for appropriate oral trials (e.g., moistened swab, ice chips, water)(19,34)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The SLP must consider the patient’s risk factors and deficits (including fatigue level, alertness, ability to participate/benefit from therapy)to determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for therapy; a multifaceted, multidisciplinary approach is indicated for patients who are in a state of coma or UWS
prognosis: In an Italian population study with 600 patients with UWS or in an MCS, researchers found that the 10-year  patient survival rate for those patients in an MCS was 4.8%(42)

In a study conducted in the Netherlands with 44 patients aged 0 to 25 years who experienced a prolonged period of disordered consciousness after severe TBI and were admitted to the Early Intensive Neurorehabilitation Programme (EINP), researchers examined the patients every 2 weeks from admission to discharge.(44) In this group of patients, researchers identified three courses of recovery: remaining in UWS (12/44); fast recovery of consciousness (discharged before the 12th week after admission; 11/44); and slow recovery of consciousness (21/44). The patients whose recovery course was labeled slow recovery of consciousness remained in an MCS and could not be discharged to an acute rehabilitation facility. In 32 of the 44 patients, researchers followed long-term  recovery for 2.0–4.4 years post discharge from the EINP using an outcome measure, the Disability Rating Scale (DRS). The DRS evaluates a patient’s disability status with scores ranging from 30 (death) to 0 (no level of disability) based on responses such as eye opening, verbal response, motor response, cognitive disability, level of function, and employability. In the group of 32, the largest group of  patients (n = 13) were labeled “moderately disabled,” which correlated to a score of 6 on the DRS. The other 19 patients’ scores were relatively evenly distributed from mildly/partially disabled (scores of 1 to 3, n = 3) to 30 (death, n = 4)

Authors of a systematic review of nontraumatic causes of coma that was published in 2015 reported that the best prognosis following nontraumatic coma was associated with patients whose disordered consciousness resulted from epilepsy (seizures) or poisoning. The worst prognosis was associated with comas resulting from stroke or anoxia(49)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral to dietitian as the patient might be at risk for malnutrition; patient might require nutritional supplements or supplemental feedings(27) Referral to physical therapy for evaluation and possible treatment Referral to occupational therapy for evaluation and possible treatment Referral to psychiatry, psychology, or social work if the patient’s family is having difficulty coping and/or may benefit from assistance with issues such as facility placement Referral to an orthotist for the fabrication of splints, orthoses, or braces
treatment summary: According to the national clinical guideline for brain injury rehabilitation in adults from the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN), there is insufficient evidence regarding nonpharmacological interventions for patients with UWS or an MCS to support a clinical guideline for practice. The evidence reviewed indicated some positive outcomes for multisensory stimulation, music therapy, contingent stimulation, and assistive technology; however, the quality of the evidence was not high enough to establish treatment efficacy(45)

Authors of a systematic review published in 2015 that was designed to both characterize rehabilitation interventions provided to patients with severe disorders of consciousness and to assess the quality of the evidence to support those interventions found 12 distinct categories of interventions, with the majority supported by expert opinion versus research-based  evidence(46) –Categories identified were nutrition, skin care, tracheostomy management and pulmonary care, bladder and bowel management, oral and dental hygiene, joint movement and ROM exercises, mobility management, prevention of secondary complications, special treatment concepts (e.g., sensory stimulation, music therapy, facio-oral  stimulation, Bobath), adaptive technology and environmental management, provision of interaction and communication, and family support –Interventions for interaction and communication included providing increased time for responses (both verbal and non-verbal)  and providing individualized means of AAC including electronic devices and yes-no  codes (e.g., eye blinking, head nodding, hand squeezing) –The researchers found that although sensory stimulation techniques were the most studied in the long-term-care population, there was insufficient evidence to either support or rule out the effectiveness of these interventions

Authors of a review of medical and surgical interventions for patients with UWS or MCS conducted by researchers in Greece in 2009 found that proposed treatments for disorders of consciousness had not yet reached the level of evidence-based  practice and most studies were inconclusive.(29) The types of interventions included in the review were: –dopaminergic agents –median nerve stimulation  –deep brain stimulation –extradural cortical stimulation –spinal cord stimulation –intrathecal baclofen

Multimodal early-onset  stimulation (MEOS)(28) –In a study conducted in Germany, researchers focused on the functional outcomes of 24 patients who sustained severe TBI resulting in a coma for over 7 days; each patient received 30–60  minutes of physical therapy, 30–60  minutes of occupational therapy, and 90 minutes of MEOS daily for an average 46.6 days; speech therapy was provided on a case-by-case  basis for those patients the SLP determined were appropriate(28) -At the start of the rehabilitation program, the patients had an average GCS score of 5.3; by discharge, the average GCS score was 7.8 -During MEOS, each modality was applied several times per day within the 90 minutes of MEOS that was incorporated into each patient’s schedule -MEOS included: -acoustic stimulation: performed by the patient’s nurse and family members; included conversation around the patient, reading books to the patient, or playing sounds/music -tactile stimulation: performed by the patient’s therapists; various types of touch were employed as well as temperature and pressure changes -olfactory: therapists exposed the patients to various familiar smells; both pleasant and unpleasant smells were used -gustatory: various foods and flavors were placed on the tongue (which was moistened prior to gustatory stimulation) using a cotton swab -visual: stimulation was provided with colored lights and variations of brightness in the room following the appropriate day-to-night  cycle -kinesthetic/proprioceptive: vestibular and proprioceptive stimulation was provided by changing the position of the body and/or extremities -Each patient’s functional status was reassessed a year after his or her TBI -6/24 (25%) of the patients had died -3/24 (12.5%) continued to exhibit UWS -6/24 (25%) were severely disabled -6/24 (25%) were moderately disabled -3/24 (12.5%) had minimal disability

A group of researchers in Germany evaluated the effects of an intensive behavioral therapy program for 7 patients with UWS or in an MCS who were residing in long-term  care facilities for over 1 year(30) –Over the course of 6 months, patients received 48 treatments per treatment block over the course of 8 weeks, 6 consecutive days a week in 30-minute  sessions; patients received therapy in either an ABA or a BAB design -Block A consisted of a sensory stimulation program -Block B consisted of a social-tactile intervention –In the sensory stimulation program, the therapist stimulated the patient’s hands and arms with a sweeping motion; additionally, objects were placed in the patient’s hand in a manner that would provide somatosensory feedback (e.g., a wooden toy that made sound when it was touched) -Positive feedback from the therapist was given when the patient responded to the stimulation -Stimulation progressed very slowly, with many repetitions -The goal of this treatment block was to create purposeful interactions between the patient and the objects –In the social-tactile  intervention program, the patient was placed in an upright, seated position -Any voluntary movement that was exhibited by the patient was verbally and physically reinforced by the therapist -The therapist monitored the patient for signs of pain or discomfort throughout each session and made positioning changes as necessary and appropriate –Over the course of the 6 months, 1 patient died from pneumonia; however, improvements in function were seen in all of the other patients. Of the 6 patients who finished the study, 5 had started the study with a diagnosis of UWS; by the end of the study all were judged to be functioning at the level of MCS by judges who were blinded to their original diagnosis and treatment design -Although both treatment programs produced improved overall functioning, data slightly favored the sensory stimulation program  -The sample of patients in this study is not large enough to make definitive statements regarding the efficacy of coma stimulation programs; however, the results showed promise and researchers recommended further investigation of these programs, with larger sample sizes

Swallowing therapy: SLPs must be cautious in providing oral trials or starting therapeutic oral feedings with patients in states of disordered consciousness; patients should have achieved a level of consciousness of at least UWS (i.e., have emerged from a coma) and the physician should provide specific guidelines for appropriate oral trials (e.g., moistened swab, ice chips, water)(19,34) –Positioning/postural adaptations: Individuals in a state of disordered consciousness who have neuromuscular abnormalities that influence feeding might benefit from changes in position. In these cases, the SLP can collaborate with a physical therapist (PT) and/or occupational therapist (OT) to determine a position that optimizes swallow function -For detailed information on postural changes as dysphagia treatment, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy –Compensatory ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T903567 –Adaptive equipment: Adaptive equipment for eating and feeding therapy will depend on the patient’s age and might include specific nipples, bottles, pacifiers, cups, spoons, and forks. The SLP can collaborate with the OT in selecting adaptive equipment for feeding -For detailed information on adaptive equipment for dysphagia, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy – Compensatory , referenced above –Modification of liquids: Liquids can be modified (e.g., thickened) to assist the patient with controlling liquids in the oral and pharyngeal phases of the swallow and improve the effectiveness and safety of the swallow. Trials of different liquid consistencies should be performed with instrumental assessments (e.g., VFSS, FEES) to determine safety. Modification of equipment such as bottles and cups might be necessary in order to accommodate the thickened liquids, and parents/ caregivers should receive training and information regarding thickened liquids. Examples of circumstances in which thickened liquids might assist the patient include: -pooling of liquid in the oral cavity(31) -poor lip closure and loss of liquid(31) -poor tongue control, movement, and coordination(31) -delayed initiation of the swallow(31) -coughing/choking/gulping(31) -clinical signs of aspiration(31) -presence of GERD(31) -For detailed information on modifications of liquids as dysphagia treatment, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy –Compensatory , referenced above –Modification of solid foods: Solid foods can be modified to assist the patient with chewing and forming/controlling the bolus. In addition, recommendations of food consistency and food type must be aligned to the family’s dietary habits and culture -For detailed information on modifications of solid foods as dysphagia treatment, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy –Compensatory , referenced above

Feeding tubes (orogastric, nasogastric, gastrostomy, jejunostomy)/enteral feeding: Decisions regarding the use of feeding tubes should be made with input from the SLP, physician, nutritionist, and other rehabilitation professionals who have professional experience and training. Individuals in disordered states of consciousness typically require a feeding tube to provide an alternative nutritional source

AAC –Working with the rehabilitation team members, the SLP can assist in the selection of assistive technology devices for communication and functional independence by determining which behavioral responses (e.g., eye blinks, thumb movements) are the most consistently accurate for the individual patient(9,10,16,17) -Microswitches can be connected to a range of devices for the patient to control his or her environment (e.g., radio, computer, television)(9,10,16,17)

Reality orientation with postcomatose patients –Immediately upon emerging from a coma, individuals typically are confused, disorientated, aphasic, and amnesic and often are cognitively impaired(26) –Speech therapy for these patients initially focuses on reorientation(26)  -Ask the family to provide familiar, personal objects such as a poster, stuffed animal, and photographs(26) -Posting a calendar in the room and changing it daily can help reorient the patient to time(26) -Provide emotional support as needed and refer to social work/mental health professional when appropriate(26) .
